questions.text: A Pt undergoes B/L adrenalectomy in view of B/l pheochromocytoma. On post op day 1 patient develops lethargy, fatigue. BP normal, pulse normal. No evidence of loss of volume. The most likely cause is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cortisol deficiency Adrenal glands secrete hormones essential for the body to:- regulate electrolytes, manage fluid balance, maintain normal BP, as well as help control the body's response to stress. Post adrenalectomy patients require close monitoring of electrolytes, especially potassium . After bilateral adrenalectom y patients may suffer from hypokalemia leading to weakness and fatigue.

Highyeild:

Short Test: 250 micrograms of cosyntropin m or i.v injection Blood cortisol levels 30-60 min (cortisol post cosyntropin is < 500 mol/l) CBC, serum Na, K, creatinine, urea, TSH For dDx : Plasma ACTH , rennin, S. aldosterone. High ACTH, high PRA, low aldosterone (primary Al) Low- normal ACTH, normal PRA and aldosterone (secondary) Adrenal autoantibody Antibodies against (steroid secreting cells, thyroid Ag, parietal cells, pancreatic cells) CBC to look for pernicious anemia Blood Ca and glucose CXR, U/S and X-ray of adrenals for TB calcifications CT or MRI of adrenals for malignancies, hemorrhage. HIV test Serum Na and K Tests for 170HP and in men plasma VLCFA. MRI pituitary for hypothalamic pituitary mass.

Extraedge:

Definition of Adrenal Insufficiency: There is a decrease in the secretion of cortisol and or aldosterone CAUSES Secondary (low ACTH) is the most common. Pituitary tumors (endocrine adenomas, rarely carcinoma) Mass lesions affecting the HP region(craniopharyngioma, meningioma, metastases). Pituitary irradiation. Pituitary apoplexy/hemorrhage. Pituitary infiltration (TB, actinomycosis, sarcoidosis, Wegener's granulomatosis, metastases). Chronic glucocorticoid excess. Primary (high ACTH) Addison's disease: Autoimmune Adrenal infection (TB, HIV, CMV, cryptococcosis, histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis). Adrenal infiltration (Metastases, lymphomas, sarcoidosis, amyloidosis, hemochromatosis). Bilateral adrenalectomy. Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD).

questions.text: Nosocomial infection called after how many hrs of hospital admission?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

48hrs Nosocomial: Originating or taking place in a hospital, acquired in a hospital, especially in reference to an infection . The term " nosocomial " comes from two Greek words: "nosus" meaning "disease" + "komeion" meaning "to take care of." Hence, "nosocomial" should apply to any disease contracted by a patient while under medical care. However, common usage of the term " nosocomial " is now synonymous with hospital-acquired. Nosocomial infections are infections that have been caught in a hospital and are potentially caused by organisms that are resistant to antibiotics.

Extraedge:

Criteria for Nosocomial infection:- A nosocomial infection is specifically one that was not present or incubating prior to the patient's being admitted to the hospital, but occurring after 48 hours after admittance to the hospital. Most common nosocomial organism:- Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Escherichia coli, Acinetobacter baumannii, and coagulase-negative staphylococcus.

questions.text: A patient on follow up for recurrent abdominal pain. USG reveals 40mm aortic aneurysm. What should be the next step?

options.label: B
options.text: Observe till it reaches 70mm & then surgery

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediate surgery An aneurysm is a localized sac or dilation formed at a weak point in the wall of the aorta. Aortic aneurysm may involve the aortic arch, thoracic aorta and or abdominal aorta. Atherosclerosis , the most common cause. It causes thinning and weakening of the media secondary to intimal plaques. Such plaques compress the underlying media. The media consequently undergoes degeneration and necrosis . Most frequently in the abdominal aorta abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) As the patient is symptomatic (recurrent abdominal pain) any size of aneurysm require immediate surgery

Highyeild:

Diagnostic studies Chest X-Ray are useful in demonstrating :- the mediastinal silhouette and any abnormal widening of the thoracic aorta. Plain X-Ray of the abdomen may show calcification within the wall of abdominal aorta aneurysms Electrocardiogram (ECG)may be performed to rule out evidence of myocardial infarction (MI) Echocardiography assists in the diagnosis of aortic valve insufficiency related to ascending aortic dilation. Ultrasonography is useful in screening for aneurysms and to serially monitor aneurysm size. CT scan is the most accurate test to determine the location and the presence of thrombus in the aneurysm. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) also may be used to diagnose and assess the location and severity of aneurysms.

Extraedge:

Causes Congenital :- primary connective tissue disorder (Marfan's syndrome, Ehlers- Danlos Syndrome) and other diseases (focal medial agenesis, tuberous sclerosis, Turner's Syndrome Menkes Syndrome) Mechanical (hemodynamic):-Poststenotic and Arteriovenous fistula and amputation related. Traumatic (pseudoaneurysms): Penetrating arterial injuries blunt arterial injuries pseudoaneurysms Inflammatory non infectious:- Associated with Takayasu arteritis giant cell arteritis systemic lupus erythematosus Behcet's syndrome, Kawasaki's disease Periarterial inflammation (i.e pancreatitis). Infectious (mycotic ): Bacterial, fungal, spirochetal infections. Pregnancy -related degenerative: Nonspecific inflammatory variant. Anastomotic (post-arteriotomy) and graft aneurysms: Infection, arterial wall failure, suture failure, graft failure.

questions.text: Most common opportunistic infection after renal transplant?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CMV Immunosuppressive drug therapy after transplant is the major cause of immunocompromised status and occurrence of opportunistic infections Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common viral infection, occurring most commonly between post transplant months 1 and 3. CMV is a herpes virus CMV is most common viral infection in solid organ transplantation Non cytomegalovirus virus infections includes varicella zoster viruses, parvovirus B-19, polyomavirus, nocardia mucormycosis.

Highyeild:

Cytomegalic Inclusion Disease CNS abnormalities microcephaly, mental retardation, spasticity, epilepsy, periventricular calcification. Eye - chorioretinitis and optic atrophy Ear - sensorineural deafness Liver - hepatosplenomegaly and jaundice which is due to hepatitis. Lung - pneumonitis Heart - myocarditis Thrombocytopenic purpura, Haemolytic anaemia Late sequelae in individuals asymptomatic at birth - hearing defects and reduced intelligence

Extraedge:

Laboratory Diagnosis Virus Isolation Conventional cell culture is regarded as the gold standard but requires up to 4 weeks for results. More useful are rapid culture methods such as the DEAFF test which can provide a result in 24-48 hours Serology The presence of CMV 1gG antibody indicates past infection. The detection of IgM is indicative of primary infection although it may also be found in immunocompromised patients with reactivation. Anti-CMV agents in current use are ganciclovir, foscarnet, and cidofovir.

questions.text: Which of the following not seen in pituitary apoplexy:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypertension Pituitary Apoplexy or Panhypopituitarism A rare but potentially life threatening clinical syndrome resulting from acute haemorrhage or infarction of pituitary gland Clinical features presents with a sudden onset of severe Headache , vomiting, visual disturbances (visual acuity impairment and visual field impairment) and decreased consciousness, Hypoglycaemia , Hypotension, Ophthalmoplegia, Death Occurrence It usually occur in presence of pituitary adenoma most commonly somatotroph or corticotroph adenoma D/D:- post-partum (Sheehan’s syndrome), Hypertension, DM, Sickle cell, Acute shock, Carotid angiography, Empty Sella syndrome, Bleeding Disorder, Anticoagulant therapy

questions.text: Frost bite patient is rewarmed at which temperature:
questions.explanation:

37 degree What is frostbite? Frostbite is a type of injury that can occur when your skin’s exposed to the cold. Cold exposure can cause the top layer of your skin and some of the tissues beneath it to freeze. Investigations Chest Radiography CECT + HRCT – Fluid, consolidation, atelectasis PCWP < 18mmHg Echocardiography BAL Precipitating cause unclear Hemodynamic instability- unsafe Management of frostbite Rapidly warming- Immersing the affected part into circulating water having temp 37- 40 degree Celsius for 30 – 60 minutes Administration of parenteral narcotics – in deep frostbite Prostacyclin analogues – within 24hrs Range of temperature for rewarming should be 37 to 40 degree Celsius so accordingly the answer should be option A that is 37 degree Celsius

questions.text: Differentiating feature between IBS and organic GI disease (IBD) is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stool calprotectin Calprotectin is a protein released by a type of white blood cell called neutrophil. When there is inflammation in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, neutrophils moves to the area and release Calprotectin, resulting in an increased level in stool. This test measures the level of Calprotectin in stool as a way to detect inflammation in the intestines. So it also differentiate the inflammatory and non inflammatory GI disease as IBD and IBS so accordingly right answer would be option C

Solution:

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness due to the alterations/marked reduction of a protein called dystrophin that helps keep muscle cells intact.

Highyeild:

Meryon's sign:- child slips through examiner's grasp when lifted under arms Possible toe-walking Can climb stairs Gower's sign climbing up legs' using the hands when rising from the floor

Extraedge:

PATHOGENESIS:- The disorder is caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene, the largest gene located on the human X chromosome which codes for the protein dystrophin Without dystrophin, muscles are susceptible to mechanical injury and undergo repeated cycles of necrosis and regeneration . Ultimately, regenerative capabilities are exhausted or inactivated Dystrophin is responsible for connecting the cytoskeleton of each muscle fiber to the underlying basal lamina The absence of dystrophin permits excess calcium to penetrate the sarcolemma leading to mitochondrial dysfunction Mitochondrial dysfunction gives rise to an amplification of stress-induced cytosolic calcium signals and an amplification of stress-induced reactive-oxygen species ( ROS ) production .
